segments.text: translation, dust covered, his eyes burning from both the sun and lack of sleep.
They had returned from the exercise, but instead of heading to the shower, he took off his shoes and entered the jeep barefoot.
He was eager to see her and drove straight to her pink house.
More than two weeks had passed since he last saw her, and two weeks before that, they had only exchanged a few words here and there.
Even then, most of their communication was through their eyes.
Ever since that emotional moment when he kissed her hand, he hadn't touched her for a month.
Only his soul was filled with her.
Every quiet moment, her face appeared before him, diving into her blue gaze as if she were beside him.
After almost two hours of driving, he parked the Jeep in the same spot where he had slept the previous time.
He removed his dusty shirt and walked towards the door barefoot and in a white t-shirt.
His hand was already on the handle to open the door when he noticed a note pinned to it that read, I'm in my place.
As he had already pressed the handle, the door opened easily.
It wasn't locked.
The place was clean and tidy.
It was clear she had taken care of it.
But there was no sign of life.
He called her name, but realized he wouldn't get a response.
Without hesitation, he went to the fridge behind the bar, took out a bottle of drink, and drank eagerly.
What would he do now?
He had no idea where her place was.
He sat wearily on the armchair in the corner.
looking at the portrait of her mother on the wall.
They looked alike, he thought, something in the wistful gaze and cheekbones.
He was almost asleep when suddenly he heard someone call out loudly.
Annabelle Lee from A Kingdom By The Sea.
The door opened and in front of him stood a sturdy, fair-haired pilot looking at him in surprise.
Who are you?
he asked.
I'm a friend from the army, he replied.
And you?
I'm something between a brother and a friend, the pilot laughed, extending his hand for a shake.
Danny.
In a routine move, Danny also made his way to the fridge, pulled out a drink, and drank thirstily.
She's in her place, Dan said, but I have no idea where that is and how to get there.
He continued in the same breath.
Tell me, is this house always unlocked?
Danny laughed.
Yes, when she's here, she doesn't lock it.
Only at night or when she returns to the army, does she lock it.
After a moment of silence, he added, I'll tell you the secret of her place.
I hope she won't kill me for it.
She goes there when she needs some peace of mind.
Is that Jeep outside yours?
Then just drive straight towards the sea.
When you reach the parking lot, go about 100 meters to the right and go down through the Ker-Kar rocks.
There's a narrow strip of beach with a creek.
That's her place.
There are no people there, and no one bothers her.
You can also find lovely shells that the sea washes ashore.
I'd come with you, but I need to go home.
I just stopped by to say hello, see that she's okay.
And what's this Annabelle Lee thing, Dan asked with a smile.
She'll tell you that.
Do you know the poem?
Yes, I do, Dan answered.
Then you'll agree with me that she's like a princess in her own kingdom by the sea.
He smiled and the commander smiled too.
Thinking that he was right.
He liked this Annabelle.
They parted with a warm handshake and Dan made his way to her hideout according to Danny's instructions.
He parked the Jeep in the organized parking lot and walked to her place.
From the height of the cliff, he already saw her wandering along the beach in her grandfather's tank top.
Pant legs rolled up, feet in the water, occasionally bending down to pick up a shell.
He descended slowly along the Kerkar rocks.
Careful not to step on the sea lilies sprouting around and walk toward her.
Suddenly she sensed she was not alone.
She raised her eyes, widened them in astonishment and began to run toward him just as he ran toward her.
They found themselves embracing in a tight hug, their first hug.
A clear, self-evident hug, knowing that there was their place, and it had always been.
He lifted and spun her in the air like a little girl.
She laughed an open, happy laugh, and when he put her back on her feet, she found his lips on hers, kissing her with deep emotion.
Her lips parted slightly, and her head was dizzy.
She held onto his neck, running her fingers through this mane, and didn't let go of his lips.
Until that moment, they hadn't said a word to each other.
Once they calmed down a bit, they sat on the warm sand, gently embracing.
He looked at her, stroking her hair and face, and suddenly said, It was so long, I could almost no longer bear it.
Such longing.
I know, me too.
That's why I went to my place," she answered quietly.
I come here when things are hard.
I seek comfort and peace.
But how did you even know where to find me?
She suddenly asked.
Realizing it was impossible, he found her alone.
Only two people knew where her place was.
Well, maybe Victor the lifeguard too.
I met Danny, who sends you a hug and hopes you won't kill him for revealing it.
And I also found out you're called Annabelle Lee.
She laughed.
When I was fourteen, our English teacher Fanny taught us Edgar Allan Poe's Annabelle Lee.
I was enchanted by the poem and would recite it for days.
Danny decided that like the girl in the poem, I was a kind of princess in a kingdom by the sea.
He's my childhood friend, and only he and doctor.
Danny know where my place is.
I wrote the note so they wouldn't worry when they saw the house open.
When I return, I never lock it.
only at night.
I don't know why.
I just kept that habit since.
You realize you're surrounded by Danies?"
he suddenly told her.
True, she laughed, surprised.
I hadn't thought about it, but you don't have a yid.
So the tip of the yid makes all the difference.
He hugged her from behind.
She leaned back against him, finding rest with the tranquility and sea in front of them, which served as a pastoral backdrop for what she felt in her heart.
When was the last time you were home?
She suddenly asked.
It occurred to her that it had been more than a month since he had seen his mother, Naomi and father, David.
They must miss him terribly.
From his reply, she realized she was right.
I have to go to them.
I have a few things to do there.
Help Dad a bit."
And Nomi hasn't felt well in the last two weeks.
She caught a flu that worsened.
Only in the last two days, she feels a bit better.
He calls her Nomi, she remembered.
At first, it seemed strange to her, but he said it with such tenderness and warmth that it sounded at least like Dear Mom.
He had kept this since he was a baby.
When he heard his father call her that, an N-O-M-I was the first word he said.
It seemed they loved it very much, his little mom.
Are you heading straight to beat Yanai?
No, I thought if it's okay, I'll stay here overnight and continue in the morning.
She was so happy to have him a bit longer, yet lifted her eyes to him.
You can sleep in the same room to make clear they still weren't sleeping together.
Slowly, slowly, he smiled, stroked her forehead, gathered her loose hair in his hands and braided it with surprising skill.
She looked up at him in surprise.
Mom taught me to braid Noga, my sister's hair when she was little.
There are four years between us, and the truth is I miss her a lot.
I haven't seen her in more than a year.
They sat, speaking their hearts, exchanging caresses, finding themselves again in a soft, long kiss, exchanging bright glances, expressing everything inside.
At moments he closed his eyes, and she thought he had fallen asleep.
He must be so tired, she thought, and maybe hungry too.
But suddenly he said, you know what?
I'd love to hear the story about your pirate.
The one left after the drillers from Texas.
You've left me so curious.
Now she laughed.
You seem exhausted.
Do you have the energy for stories?
Yes, please.
The day Jerry Wolf entered her life, she hadn't yet turned five.
He had entered through their door, almost filling the entire entrance.
His head was adorned with reddish curls streaked with silver and a small beard grew on his chin.
He smiled a childish smile but emphasized the large dimple on his right cheek, extended a hand to Joseph and said, Hi, I'm Jerry, Jerry Wolf.
Is there any beer in the bar?
Joseph laughed and replied, Since you are already here, have one on the house.
She had to stretch her little neck to see him clearly, staring at him in growing amazement.
And when she discovered the small hoop earrings in his ears, she clung to Joseph's leg, tightened her grip on his hand, raised her head to him and asked, Is he a pirate?
Oh, how he laughed when Joseph translated her question for him.
In a second, he was leaning the side her, smiling his dimpled smile and
through Joseph's translation, said his mom had given them to him because he always came home wet from the stream near his house.
And she would hang him up by the earrings to dry.
She laughed too, even understanding at her very young age that it was a joke.
He immediately captured her heart.
He was the first man she saw with an earring and she was fascinated.
And Lucy said so too.
It's hard to believe, but Jerry Wolf, who looked as if he had stepped out of a fairy tale.

Towering as tall as a cypress, with his childlike face, dimple, curls, beard, and small hoop earrings, was an engineer, a world-renowned expert on pumping machines, sent to set up the pumping station in the Yarkon Springs.
Before he arrived at their inn, he had been almost everywhere in the world, in China, India, Hong Kong, Spain, France, Portugal, and where not.
One could listen to his stories for hours and a deep friendship formed between him and Joseph, who Jerry called Joe.
He settled into their pink inn, and every day made his way to the Yarkon Springs in Rowsha Ion and back.
He would not hear of moving closer to his work.
Immediately when he returned from it, a minute after parking his Jeep, his figure would fill the entire doorway, and she would run to him.
He would give her that dimpled smile and ask in English, what does Jerry want?
And she would run to the fridge while answering, beer, pulling out a beer bottle and handing it to him.
without a glass and without an opener.
He would open the bottle with his teeth and drink straight from it, and little Leora would sit beside him, sometimes on his lap.
Deep within her very young heart, fueled by her vivid imagination, she was sure he was, after all, some kind of pirate.
When he finished, he would look at her with a mischievous expression in his eyes and ask,
And what does Jerry want now?
And she was already at the fridge answering another beer and handed him another bottle.
Only after the third bottle would he calm down and announce that he was going to shower.
He would arrive for dinner as polished as a groom for his wedding.
His curls still damp and glistening, dressed in jeans, but always with a neatly ironed white shirt tucked into his pants.
adorned with a large shiny belt buckle and cowboy boots equally polished on his feet.

Until he went to sleep around midnight, sometimes later, he would sit in the bar, talking with Lucy and Joseph, sometimes with other guests, consuming at least 10 beer bottles, occasionally spicing it up with a whiskey on the rocks.
When he would make his way to his room, he still stood on his feet as if nothing.
Lucy used to say that since Jerry had been with them, the beer business in the country was thriving.
She would never forget that one time when Kim didn't return home and it was already starting to get dark.
And Lucy said.
Where on earth is that dog wandering?
And all her whistles did no good.
He saw tears welling up in her little eyes, reached out his arms and lifted her into the jeep.
Come on, we'll find him, he said.
They circled all the places.
She used to wander with him, Jerry trying to mimic Lucy's whistles, but to no avail.
There was no trace of Kim.

Just when they were about to give up and head home, they suddenly saw him coming up the path from the direction of the dune, strolling with the indifference of a dog, completely unaware of the drama he had caused.
She told Jerry he probably fell asleep on the warm sand in the dune, feeling the need to justify him.
He's crazy about the girl.
Lucy used to say to Joseph and he would reply that it's because he doesn't have a family of his own.
kill me if I understand how a man like that doesn't have a wife," he would say from time to time.
One day, Lucy quietly looked Joseph in the eyes and said, honestly, Joseph, I'm not sure women are what he loves, and now he doesn't need a family.
He has us.
Two years later, Jerry Wolf exited her life, handed her a small box wrapped in colored paper, hugged her long, and then turned and left, unable to stand the farewell.
Lucy helped her open the box, and there on a small cushion lay a small earring he had removed from one of his ears.
He left the other earring in the other ear, so they would forever share the earrings.
He left our lives, leaving one little girl with a broken heart, one father missing him for long days, and pumps operating in the Yarkon Springs to this very day.
And so she concluded with dramatic solemnity, Jerry Wolf.
As tall as a cypress, with his curls, beard, his dimple, and small hoop earrings in his ears, appeared for a brief moment in my life and remained my private pirate forever.
Dan looked at her gently, full of admiration for the way she narrated her life, and no less for the content itself, as if she were drawing chapters from a children's fairy tale.
The sun was already halfway down, setting into the sea in front of them.
She held his hand and said, Come on, let's go home.
You can shower and eat something.
You're exhausted.
Side by side, their pant edges rolled up, feet barefoot and wet, her hand in his, and in her other hand, the beautiful shells she had gathered.
They climbed up the cliff, leaving her place.
This is the season of the sea lilies, she explained.
Look how beautiful it is, how they pop up almost everywhere between the Kirker rocks, like a garden no one waters.
She has a poetic soul.
He thought to himself as he held her hand tightly, helping her on the last stretch.
He really liked the way she had elegantly clarified that he was to sleep alone.
He gave her a soft glance from the side, and suddenly the thought came to him that life was still ahead of them.
What's the rush?
Something very deep wove between them.
He had never felt this way before.
There was a sense that it wasn't just deep, but also right and good.
A calm understanding filled the space between them without words.
Still, he waited for those words to explain, to tell.
Although she still kept most of her secrets to herself, he knew she trusted him and the day would come when she would tell him more.

Strangely, he thought to himself how the independent, opinionated and free-spirited young woman made him want to protect her, although on the surface she seemed to manage wonderfully and bravely on her own.
They walked barefoot for the hundred meters to the parking lot.
Small stones pressed into their feet along the way, but it didn't bother her.
She was used to it.
It appeared that Dan, too, was unfazed by the rough path they walked.
Great, she thought to herself, we have yet another thing in common besides the love for the sea, books, horses, and dogs.
We love being barefoot.
She peaked at his handsome profile, at his dust-covered curls that needed a wash so badly.
and her heart went out to him.
Her hand in his, the shells in her other hand.
From the height of the parking lot, the lifeguard's hot look down at them.
Come on, let's just quickly go down to the beach to say hello to Victor the lifeguard.
She suddenly said, I haven't seen him for months.
And if I'm already here at
would be nice to say hi.
This was exactly the hour when Victor used to close the sea.
She saw him bent over a haasek near the hut and shouted, V-I-C-T-O-R.
He raised his head, recognized her, and a huge smile revealing white teeth spread across his suntanned face.
He waved to her in greeting.
She didn't notice, but her hand was no longer in Dan's.
She quickened her pace to almost a run, and already he was warmly hugging her shoulders.
So good to see you, since you joined the army, practically disappeared on me.
I know you go to your place.
Of course, I know.
Victor knows everything happening by the sea.
He testified about himself.
But that's all right.
Everyone needs to have their own place.
Dan was already beside them.
Meet Dan, my boyfriend.
He's with me in the army.
So naturally it came to her, my boyfriend.
Nice to meet you.
Victor shook his hand.
I've known your girlfriend since she was a little girl.
And if you ask me, nothing has changed since.
She remains a free-spirited bird.
And from coming to the sea so much, the sea color stuck to her eyes.
He laughed.
You've chosen the best girl.
Well, no need to exaggerate, she said with a smile.
I just wanted to say hello, so you know I'm still alive.
You finish closing your sea and we'll be off.
Once they were already in the Jeep, she suddenly said, from the moment the sea opened at the start of summer until it closed at the end of autumn.
I'd spend every free moment at the beach near Victor's lifeguard hut.
You came to the sea in a Jeep, so you didn't notice it, but my pink house sits exactly where the path leading to the sea begins.
She continued telling him that when she was very young, perhaps in second grade, Joseph, her dad, taught her to swim.
He taught her to swim in the sea, not in a pool because there wasn't one in Ashkelon.
In the early times, she'd swallow some salt water and choke.
But after repeated attempts, she could hold her head above the water nicely and coordinate her arm movements with her legs.
Then, knowing he could trust her not to drown easily, he'd let her come to the sea alone, leaving her in Victor's care.
She'd walk alone along the path from her house to the sea.
Maybe a 10-minute walk, maybe less, straight to Victor's hut, who'd watch over her.
Kekeets and I, Joseph would tell Lucy to keep her from worrying.
He didn't just watch over her.
Occasionally, Victor would call her up to the hut, offer her a towel, give her a drink, treat her to a fricassee sandwich, or cut her a slice of cold watermelon, and then send her back to the waves.
Lucy and Joseph never went to the sea, mainly because they didn't have time for it.
Most of the time, they were occupied with the guests at the hotel.
But Joseph knew how to swim excellently from the days he used to carry illegal immigrants on his back at the Atlet Beach.

and help port workers in jaffa and lucy she might visit the delilah cafe once a year just before winter broke in and victor the lifeguard officially closed the sea sinning with a drink and gazing into the waves she had been telling stories for a long time not noticing it fully immersed in memories with a soft expression on her face finally she starts to tell he thought to himself
seems like you had a wonderful childhood in that house of yours.
She looked at him, realizing she had poured her heart out to him without noticing, but suddenly felt it was okay to tell him.
Yes, you're right.
This house was like a wonder world for me.
And I was Alice.
She paused for a moment and then an unclear expression spread across her face.
Until the end of the beginning came, she added.
Now he saw a cloud overshadowing her eyes.
He took her hand, just like the first time in the Jeep, turned her palm over and kissed the inside.
Immediately he saw how the cloud disappeared and she returned to being soft with gleaming eyes.
How she loved their togetherness.
After they were washed and clean, Dan sat at the bar with a beer glass, looked around and began to feel at home among the paintings on the walls and the vast garden visible through the glass doors.
Yet he realized he had no idea how she managed everything alone, casually, with nothing seeming too difficult.
She was now in the kitchen, beyond the wall, preparing their meal.
He started setting the table for both of them when she said, Prepare another place.
Someone always joins when they sense I'm around.
He remembered the doctor from last time and understood she was right.
He drank from the beer in his glass.
He hadn't drunk beer for a long time.
He hadn't gone out, hardly seen the outside due to the intense army activity.
He felt how wonderfully it went down his throat.
The bitter taste he loved so much.
It was she who asked if he'd like to have a beer, pouring him a glass perfectly like a professional, tilting the glass to avoid foam.
He stared at her.
Sometimes he felt as if there was an instruction book inside her written from years of observation.
So were the dishes she prepared.
For a moment, he thought that part of her childhood had been taken away, maybe her youth, forced to suddenly turn from a child to an adult, with great responsibility weighing on her shoulders.
He was surprised when she poured herself a beer too.
I'm a child robbed of reverse psychology, she laughed.
My dad tried to teach me to drink brandy at fifteen and offered me a cigarette at sixteen.
The brandy burned my soul and I was not willing to hear about cigarettes.
They were both heavy smokers, mom with her dubeck ten and him with his nelson without a filter and there was always smoke around.
Even the armchair in the corner would occasionally catch fire when they fell asleep for a short rest, cigarette in mouth, in the afternoon.
It's an embracing armchair, rather wide, soft, and you can almost hide in it.
In moments of tranquility and solitude, I'd curl up in it, tucking my feet under me, sinking into endless book reading.
Sometimes when I'm nestled in it, I am guilty of a light nap, a good nap, sneaking up on you without you noticing, and you wake up from it quiet and in good spirits.
As she spoke, fully immersed in memories, her face took on a kind and pensive expression.
Once again he felt as though she was telling her life like a story, describing smells and feelings, which made him experience everything she described.
That's why I can't stand cigarettes, she concluded.
I'm so glad you don't smoke.
But I do love beer and wine.
I don't drink much, only occasionally.
But I like it.
My previous boyfriend used to drink a lot of beer.
He sat up suddenly.
You had a boyfriend before me?
Yes, she smiled with enjoyment at his response, until a year and a half ago.
He returned abroad and after a long period of endless letters he released me on my way.
At first my heart was a bit broken but from the start there was something almost impossible about it and I suppose I was prepared for him to vanish from my life at some stage.
There was a period of quite a bit of longing but now it's just a pleasant memory.
Since then I didn't have a boyfriend nor did I want one.
I have enough troubles to deal with, it just wasn't in my plans.
She paused for a moment and then added, until you came and without intention, slipped right into my heart, leaving me with no escape.
She looked deep into his eyes as if saying yes.
That's exactly where you've settled in me, deep inside my heart, he said without thinking, and who wants to escape?
He smiled tenderly, stroking her cheek, bringing his lips to hers, kissing her long and deeply.
No one joined them this time, as if everyone understood they should be left alone.
He wanted to ask her so many questions about the previous boyfriend, about how she lives alone in that house and manages it like a grownup, and what's going on with her painting father.
But he did not ask.
He realized that bit by bit, the stories would come out when she chose, not if he rushed her.
They finished their meal, and by the time she finished with the dishes, he sat in that embracing armchair in the corner.
And as she said, without realizing it, exhaustion overcame him and he fell asleep.
While washing the dishes in the kitchen, she decided that she needed to tell him.
She wanted to tell him that the house was no longer her own, that it was just temporary, maybe a long temporary, but eventually she would have to return it.
She felt the need to share this with him, to cleanse the lies she might have let him understand, even if not spoken aloud.
Now that they are in love, he deserves to know the truth.
She began to walk to the armchair, saying, Look, Dan, I need to tell you something.
But when she stood over him, she saw he was deeply asleep.
She gently stroked his head.
She called his name quietly once more and again until he opened his eyes.
Go to sleep.
You're exhausted.
This is what came out instead of what she planned to say.
It would have to wait.
He slowly rose from the armchair, standing drowsily in front of her, pulling her to his chest and kissing her repeatedly, not wanting to let go.
I'll leave early tomorrow, and I might not see you.
My operational schedule for next week is still unclear.
I might disappear again for a week or two.
Will you wait for me?"
She smiled at him fondly, running her hand through his mane of hair.
Of course, she said.
The next morning when he left, she didn't see him, and not during the entire following week either.
